ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to build, launch, market, and fund for a product.
Product design, prototyping on a deadline, more confidence with my hands-on engineering skills like arduino, CAD, laser cutting

I learned so much about coding and engineering in this course. I am a MCDB major so I didn't really know how engineering practices are usually done, but it was wonderful to explore and learn at the CEID.
What considerations go into product design, entrepreneurship basics, how to design a product.
Whirlwind tour of design, entrepreneurship, and the creative process. I also learned many skills related to my final project.

Each student might learn different skills depending on their project, but overall I think we all breached out in so many areas, had to complete tutorials, reach out and interview experts, and make decisions. We also learned a lot about what entrepreneurship looks like in the real world.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course introduced us to interesting people working on interesting products, although I wish we could have seen more live demos of products in class.

Great speakers, great people, and I really enjoyed working on projects. I was bummed that we couldn't do the speaker project or anything close to that. I also wish Joe had listened to students more about aspects of the course/been more present during project periods; the TA's really took up the role that he typically has and made this a great experience. Also the class information was posted basically two days before shopping period which meant that most people didn't know that this class was going to happen -- I would NOT have seen it if I didn't happen to look right before classes started. But overall a wonderful experience and will definitely be better when it's back in person!
No more covid pandemic. Otherwise, it was great!

I liked the class mostly. It was pretty inspiring to hear the stories of so many people who "made it" in product design. I was very disappointed to find that the famous Bluetooth speaker making project had been cancelled and replaced with simply CAD-ing the speaker. This class would have been much better in-person. The TAs were absolutely fantastic! They were much more involved in our projects than Joe was.
strengths are definitely the teaching staff -- they were amazing!

This was a great class! It is very engaging and fun, and you get to work very closely with the TA's and the professor. There is a lot of guidance and resources to have a fun time learning. Because this semester was virtual,  we didn't get to build the speaker project which was sad. We also didn't get to work at the CEID.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout sessions and discussions about class speakers before class were engaging
More in-person engineering work before projects were launched.

I did not like the fact that there was no in-person component to the class. I hated not being able to make anything until we started our final projects. Also, working in teams was much harder over Zoom. We didn't have much work time; Joe would often spend most of the class time talking about something or another. Some of the discussion felt forced.
The course worked well online. The Kickstarter final was really fun to make and there was a wide range of guest speakers that zoomed in.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you would like to develop a product from ideation to creation
Yes! If you want to build something, learn about product design, and build the bones of a business. Just know that this is a lot of work and your team members can make or break the experience.
Yes! You just have to be motivated and creative!
Absolutely! Especially if you can take it in person.
100% recommend if the idea of creating something or learning new skills through projects excites you

Yes! the first part of the course was pretty chill but things did pick up quickly when working on the projects. It's so great getting to work on a project you are interested in and passionate about. Very proud of the work I did in this class and would take it over and over if I could.
Yes! So fun to create a project. The class itself is really fun as well and it was nice getting close to my peers.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Received help for class projects from TAs in the CEID
Prototyping in person for students.
We also had a project component, where we needed to go into the CEID to do the project.

Somewhere between lecture and seminar. We had a lot of guest speakers come in and talk about their work. We also had some work days where we worked with our teams in breakout rooms. Joe and the TAs would visit each group.
